bioghist.p: Philip Sheeder Landes (1883-1967) was born in Brazil. He studied at the American School in Curitiba and then at Mackenzie College in Sao Paolo. He graduated from the College of Wooster and Princeton Theological Seminary. In 1915 he returned to Brazil with his wife, Margaret Bookwalter Landes (d. 1969), as a missionary of the Presbyterian Church, USA. Landes made an extensive journey of missionary exploration with the Rev. Franklin Graham, across the states of Baia, Goias, and Mato Grosso. With his wife, he worked in Cuiaba for 15 years, establishing churches in Cuiaba and several other locations. After his years in Mato Grosso, he became the evangelist-at-large for the Central Brazil Mission from 1930 to 1935. He then served as a professor of Church History and other courses at the Theological Seminary in Campinas, Brazil, until his retirement in 1954.

scopecontent.p: The collection contains diaries (1913-1965, incomplete); minutes of the Central and Southern Brazil Missions (1921-1940 and 1952); reports; correspondence (much of it copies of Landes' outgoing letters, 1941-1959, in English and Portuguese); newsletters and account books (1943-1965); publications, including published volumes on missionary work and a range of theological topics (many in Portuguese); sermons; and newspapers. There are also journals of the Seminario Teologico Presbiteriano de Campinas and the faculty of the Igraja Crista Presbiteriana da Brazil; copies of "Brazil Notes," from 1973-1975; a typed history of the Presbyterian Church in Brazil (in Portuguese); notes for lectures, talks and sermons (some sermon notes are in Portuguese); and manuscripts, including a manuscript for "The Case for Medical Missions and Evangelism in Brazil" and "A New Evaluation of Infant Baptism" by Landes, 1939. The collection also includes architectural plans.
